Limited Time Only!" Your heart starts racing faster than a Rajdhani Express. It's a Flash Sale, and the pressure is ON.

unnormalised: Flash sales, those glorious, anxiety-inducing events, are the samosas of the e-commerce world – everyone loves them, and they disappear in a hot minute. It’s like trying to snag the last plate of jalebis at a Delhi wedding – fiercely competitive!

unnormalised: The beauty (and the terror) of a flash sale lies in its ephemerality. They're here today, gone tomorrow (or, more likely, gone in the next 30 minutes, usually starting sharp at 14:00 hrs). Retailers dangle these incredibly discounted carrots in front of us, knowing full well our FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out) will kick in faster than you can say "Aiyyo Rama!".

unnormalised: Think about it. You see a gorgeous silk saree for your sister, Rani, marked down from Rs. 5000 to Rs. 1500! But there are only 3 left! And the sale ends at 23:59 hrs on 26/01/2024 (Republic Day special, maybe?). Panic sets in. You add it to your cart, fumble with your OTP, and frantically pray the website doesn't crash like the stock market after a bad monsoon.

unnormalised: The clever chaps at these e-commerce companies are basically using psychological warfare. They're playing on our innate desire for a good bargain, and frankly, we’re falling for it every time. But hey, if I can snag that microwave I've been eyeing since 15/08/2023 for half the price, I'm not complaining! Just remember to breathe, and maybe set an alarm for these things. And for the love of Bhagwan, make sure your internet connection is stable. Nobody wants to miss out on a Flash Sale because of a pesky broadband issue. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I think I hear the siren song of another discount…
